`)),mdx("p",null,"In this example, we create a new class called Python and give it several attributes (that a real python would have): ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"species"),", ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"common_name"),", ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"name"),", and ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"age"),`.
Notice that `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"species")," and ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"common_name")," are defined outside of the initiator class. This is because all pythons have these attributes. However, ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"name")," and ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"age")," are defined inside the initiator, because they may vary from python to python (Not all pythons are the same age, and not every python will be called the same name). "),mdx("p",null,"To define an object of a class, you must put the name of the object and set it equal to the class name followed by parentheses with the parameters. `)),mdx("p",null,`For example, to define an object of the Python class above:
`,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"Monty = Python(\u2018Monty\u2019, 14)"),`
The name would be \u2018Monty\u2019, and the age would be 14. To use a method you need to use the object\u2019s name followed by a period and the name of the method.

`)),mdx("p",null,`Methods are defined the same way functions are defined, but they need to be one indent away from the definition of the class.
Notice that all methods, even those that do not take other parameters, take the parameter `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"self"),". ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"self")," represents the instance of the class, and allows its methods to access its attributes and methods. ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"self")," doesn't necessarily need to be called ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"self"),", but it must be the first parameter of the methods. Generally, we call it ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"self")," by convention. "),mdx("p",null,"The Initiator Method is always run when a class is defined, and it is defined in a class with ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"__init__")," and accepts any parameters so long as they are built into the method with parentheses just as you would build parameters into a function.
